content:
Suppose I have a fully faithful functor f ⁣:A→Bf \colon A \rightarrow Bf:A→B. Let iA ⁣:A0→Ai_{A} \colon A_{0} \rightarrow AiA​:A0​→A denote the inclusion of the discrete category of objects. Does this pair of functors always admit a [[pushout complement]]?

I think the pushout complement PPP should have the same objects as BBB, such that P(fa,fa′)=∅P(fa, fa') = \emptyset P(fa,fa′)=∅ if a≠a′a \neq a'a=a′, P(fa,fa)={∗}P(fa, fa) = \{ \ast \}P(fa,fa)={∗}, and P(x,y)=B(x,y)P(x, y) = B(x, y)P(x,y)=B(x,y) otherwise. Then the functor A0→PA_{0} \rightarrow PA0​→P should be fully faithful (which is necessary for its pushout along iAi_{A}iA​ to be fully faithful), and the functor P→BP \rightarrow BP→B is identity-on-objects.

Thinking more about this, I believe we also need to assume that fff is injective-on-objects. Otherwise we have a counterexample where AAA is the [[walking isomorphism]] and BBB is the terminal category.

I think the pushout of those functors will be the disjoint union of AAA with B∖AB\setminus AB∖A. You're missing all the morphisms from objects in the image of AAA to those not in its image, and vice versa.

Mike Shulman said:

You're missing all the morphisms from objects in the image of AAA to those not in its image, and vice versa.

Right. When I write P(x,y)=B(x,y)P(x, y) = B(x, y)P(x,y)=B(x,y), I mean that at most one of x or y is in the image of AAA. In particular, I mean that P(fa,y)=B(fa,y)P(fa, y) = B(fa, y)P(fa,y)=B(fa,y) and P(x,fa)=B(x,fa)P(x, fa) = B(x, fa)P(x,fa)=B(x,fa) for a∈A a \in Aa∈A and x,y∉im(f)x, y \notin im(f)x,y∈/im(f).
The otherwise was doing a lot of work in the first statement and was a bit unclear.
Oh, I see. But then you can't compose a morphism fa→yfa \to yfa→y with a morphism y→fa′y \to fa'y→fa′.

Ah perfect, so that gives a counter-example. Take the functor {0<2}→{0<1<2}\{ 0 < 2 \} \rightarrow \{ 0 < 1 < 2 \}{0<2}→{0<1<2}. Then the ''pushout complement'' that I try to construct above doesn't work.

I am curious now as to what (neccesary and) sufficient conditions on f ⁣:A→Bf \colon A \rightarrow Bf:A→B are such that its pushout complement with iA ⁣:A0→Ai_{A} \colon A_{0} \rightarrow AiA​:A0​→A exists.
It's tempting to add the condition [[Conduche functor]] to the above assumptions, but this feels more like ``plugging the hole'' in the above counter-example rather than actually getting to the bottom of the problem.

Actually that's an interesting question: what does it mean for a full subcategory to be a Conduche functor? A full subcategory is a fibration iff it's a [[sieve]], and an opfibration iff it's a cosieve, but I haven't thought about fully faithful Conduche functors before.

However, I don't think that will work either, because in that case the span P←A0→AP \leftarrow A_0 \to AP←A0​→A still doesn't contain any information about the composites of the arrows in AAA with the arrows not in AAA, so it can't be expected to give back BBB.

Take {0<1}→{0<1<2}\{ 0 < 1 \} \to \{0 < 1 < 2\}{0<1}→{0<1<2}: then PPP has 0<20<20<2 and 1<21<21<2 but not 0<10<10<1, so the pushout will have two arrows 0→20\to 20→2, one coming from PPP and one being the freely generated composite of the 0<10<10<1 in AAA with the 1<21<21<2 in PPP.
Looking at that, I'm tempted to guess the answer is that it only holds if AAA is complemented, B=A⊔(B∖A)B = A \sqcup (B\setminus A)B=A⊔(B∖A).

Mike Shulman said:

Take {0<1}→{0<1<2}\{ 0 < 1 \} \to \{0 < 1 < 2\}{0<1}→{0<1<2}: then PPP has 0<20<20<2 and 1<21<21<2 but not 0<10<10<1, so the pushout will have two arrows 0→20\to 20→2, one coming from PPP and one being the freely generated composite of the 0<10<10<1 in AAA with the 1<21<21<2 in PPP.

So for that example, I think that the pushout complement PPP should be the category {0}⊔{1<2}\{0\} \sqcup \{1 < 2 \}{0}⊔{1<2}, but that doesn't agree with the construction I attempted to describe above.
Hmm, yes, that does seem to give a pushout complement in that case.

Mike Shulman said:

Looking at that, I'm tempted to guess the answer is that it only holds if AAA is complemented, B=A⊔(B∖A)B = A \sqcup (B\setminus A)B=A⊔(B∖A).

Just checking: what is the category (B∖A)(B \setminus A)(B∖A)? Is it just the full subcategory of BBB determined by the objects not in the image of f ⁣:A→B f \colon A \rightarrow Bf:A→B?
Yes, that's what I meant.

Let's see, let f:A↪Bf:A\hookrightarrow Bf:A↪B be a full subcategory inclusion that is a Conduche functor, and B′B'B′ the full subcategory of BBB on the complement of AAA. Then Conduche-ness of fff means that no object of B′B'B′ can be both the codomain of an arrow whose domain is in AAA and the domain of an arrow whose codomain is in AAA. So we can partition the objects of B′B'B′ into B0B_0B0​, which have an arrow to AAA, B1B_1B1​ which have an arrow from AAA, and B2B_2B2​ which have neither.

There can be no arrows from B1B_1B1​ to B0B_0B0​, from B1B_1B1​ to B2B_2B2​, or from B2B_2B2​ to B0B_0B0​. So BBB admits a functor to the walking commutative square, with fibers B0B_0B0​, AAA, B2B_2B2​, and B1B_1B1​.

Given the categories B′B'B′ and AAA, the additional data consists of two profunctors H1:B1⇸AH_1 : B_1 ⇸ AH1​:B1​⇸A, H2:A⇸B0H_2:A ⇸ B_0H2​:A⇸B0​, and a morphism α:H2∘H1→hom⁡B\alpha : H_2 \circ H_1 \to \hom_Bα:H2​∘H1​→homB​.

Whereas the data of PPP consists of, in addition to B′B'B′, profunctors K1:B1⇸ob(A)K_1 : B_1 ⇸ ob(A)K1​:B1​⇸ob(A), K2:ob(A)⇸B0K_2:ob(A) ⇸ B_0K2​:ob(A)⇸B0​, and a morphism β:K2∘K1→hom⁡B\beta : K_2 \circ K_1 \to \hom_Bβ:K2​∘K1​→homB​.

There's a forgetful functor (H1,H2,α)↦(K1,K2,β)(H_1,H_2,\alpha) \mapsto (K_1,K_2,\beta)(H1​,H2​,α)↦(K1​,K2​,β), and taking the pushout should be its left adjoint. So I figure the condition on fff -- which is admittedly not a very nice one -- is that (H1,H2,α)(H_1,H_2,\alpha)(H1​,H2​,α) is in the image of this left adjoint.

Thanks, I think I am following (although I think that B0B_0B0​ and B1B_1B1​ should be swapped in the profunctors HiH_iHi​ and KiK_iKi​?).
So the forgetful functor is given by some pasting of α\alphaα with 2-cells in ProfProfProf using the representable profunctors of iA ⁣:ob(A)→Ai_{A} \colon ob(A) \rightarrow AiA​:ob(A)→A? (I think this should be straightforward, I just can't "see" it when I write it down).
I wonder if things simplify somewhat if we assume that H1H_1H1​ or H2H_2H2​ is the initial profunctor (or that B0B_0B0​ or B1B_1B1​ is empty).

Hmmm, I guess this is obvious but if the pushout complement of (iA ⁣:A0→A,f ⁣:A→B)(i_{A} \colon A_{0} \rightarrow A, f \colon A \rightarrow B)(iA​:A0​→A,f:A→B) exists, it must also be a pullback square.
Maybe your conventions about profunctors are the opposite of mine? (-:
For me a profunctor A⇸BA⇸BA⇸B is a functor Bop×A→SetB^{\rm op}\times A \to \rm SetBop×A→Set.

Bryce Clarke said:

So the forgetful functor is given by some pasting of α\alphaα with 2-cells in ProfProfProf using the representable profunctors of iA ⁣:ob(A)→Ai_{A} \colon ob(A) \rightarrow AiA​:ob(A)→A?

Yes. It may be easier to see in the double category Prof than in the bicategory Prof, where instead of representable profunctors you can use vertical arrows: tikzcd.

Mike Shulman said:

Whereas the data of PPP consists of, in addition to B′B'B′, profunctors K1:B1⇸ob(A)K_1 : B_1 ⇸ ob(A)K1​:B1​⇸ob(A), K2:ob(A)⇸B0K_2:ob(A) ⇸ B_0K2​:ob(A)⇸B0​, and a morphism β:K2∘K1→hom⁡B\beta : K_2 \circ K_1 \to \hom_Bβ:K2​∘K1​→homB​.

So the idea is that K1:B1⇸ob(A)K_1 : B_1 ⇸ ob(A)K1​:B1​⇸ob(A) is the subset of B(fa,b)B(fa, b)B(fa,b) determined by the morphisms which do not arise from the composition with a non-identity arrow in the image of AAA?

Mike Shulman said:

There's a forgetful functor (H1,H2,α)↦(K1,K2,β)(H_1,H_2,\alpha) \mapsto (K_1,K_2,\beta)(H1​,H2​,α)↦(K1​,K2​,β), and taking the pushout should be its left adjoint. So I figure the condition on fff -- which is admittedly not a very nice one -- is that (H1,H2,α)(H_1,H_2,\alpha)(H1​,H2​,α) is in the image of this left adjoint.

I guess I am failing to come up with an example where this condition does not hold; that is, a full subcategory inclusion f ⁣:A→Bf \colon A \rightarrow Bf:A→B which is a Conduche functor and does not admit a pushout complement with the inclusion iA ⁣:A0→Ai_{A} \colon A_{0} \rightarrow AiA​:A0​→A. I will keep thinking about it.

Bryce Clarke said:

I am curious now as to what (neccesary and) sufficient conditions on f ⁣:A→Bf \colon A \rightarrow Bf:A→B are such that its pushout complement with iA ⁣:A0→Ai_{A} \colon A_{0} \rightarrow AiA​:A0​→A exists.
It's tempting to add the condition [[Conduche functor]] to the above assumptions, but this feels more like ``plugging the hole'' in the above counter-example rather than actually getting to the bottom of the problem.

I should mention that it is not necessary for a full subcategory inclusion f ⁣:A→Bf \colon A \rightarrow Bf:A→B to be a Conduche functor for its pushout complement along iA ⁣:A0→Ai_{A} \colon A_{0} \rightarrow AiA​:A0​→A to exist. For example, take AAA to be the terminal category, BBB to be the free standing section-retraction pair, and fff to pick out the initial object.

So I guess the question is whether it is a sufficient condition.
More generally, whenever AAA is discrete, iAi_AiA​ is an isomorphism, so the pushout complement always exists.

Bryce Clarke said:

So the idea is that K1:B1⇸ob(A)K_1 : B_1 ⇸ ob(A)K1​:B1​⇸ob(A) is the subset of B(fa,b)B(fa, b)B(fa,b) determined by the morphisms which do not arise from the composition with a non-identity arrow in the image of AAA?

Well, it's more general than that. You would want to take (K1,K2,β)(K_1,K_2,\beta)(K1​,K2​,β) to be some "freely generating subset" of (H1,H2,α)(H_1,H_2,\alpha)(H1​,H2​,α).
